Hi_Its_Me

As promised, I have put together some solid evidence for evolution. If you have anything to add to the list, please post it.[*]The two most obvious structures are the tonsils and the appendix. View the links for information regarding their "usefulness."[*]Another fairly obvious example is the coccyx. It is similar to the previous two in that it has a function but is not perfect or even very good for that function. Unlike the previous two, however, it is associated with a completely vestigial structure: the human tail.[*]Another example of structures that are obviously not used for their original (true) purpose are the wings of flightless birds.[*]Similarly, whales have retained their hind limb bones, "finger" bones in their forelimbs, and a very small layer of fur.[*]Human wisdom teeth are present but often unusable. Like the appendix and tonsils, if they don't work, they create substantial problems for people.
 
 Moving on to less well known examples...
 
 [*]A blind fish has no use for eyes, but it has the obvious remnants of them.[*]One response to stress is the formation of goose bumps. This response was practiced successfully by animals with more hair (i.e. our ancestors) to create the illusion of size. Now goose bumps are only useful when cold, but stress triggers them nonetheless.[*]Marsupials produce eggshells during development, but those are reabsorbed before birth.[*]Mitochondria and chloroplasts contain (and use) DNA, even though no other organelle needs it. This is an indicator that they were once separate organisms, as organelles are generally formed according to the main cellular DNA.Again, if you have anything to add, please do so.
prschuster
That's a very good website. But no amount of evidence will ever convince a confirmed creationist. As I always say: "You can show them the evidence, but you can't open their eyes.".
electrolyte

The two most obvious structures are the tonsils and the appendix.

 Frankly, I think the tailbone is more obvious than the tonsils. Nonetheless, we have many, many from which to choose.
 
 Have you seen Oolon's list of Some More of God's Greatest Mistakes? It's a humongous list of things of this sort that we wouldn't expect to see from creation (but would from evolution).
 
 I contacted Oolon a short while back about two I'd like to see added, nasal drainage and -- an even better one, IMO -- the human plantaris muscle. I've yet to see a creationist explanation of that one...
 
 By the way, chloroplasts have their own DNA, too.
pandion

My wife had her appendix and tonsils removed before I even met her. She seems to get along fine without them. Both of my sons have their appendix. My younger son had his tonsils removed in his early 20s. The only result has been fewer sore throats. I still have my tonsils after lots and lots of years. However, my appendix burst about 1 1/2 years ago. I actually can't say that there is any discernible difference in my life with an appendix as opposed to my life without it.
 
 In discussion of vestigial organs, one must always be aware of the fact that there is no claim that they serve no function, but that the function is no longer essential, being adequately served by other organs. Moreover, the sign of a vestigial organ is that it no longer serves its original function.
obvious_child

Creationism is true. Evolution is a lie! You're all going to Hell.
 
 PrAiSe GoD and like Whatever!emoticon_xgood

 Now I have, and I have to say that I'm impressed. Maybe I'll just link there from now on. Thanks!

 I remember that now, but it must have slipped my mind when I was writing the above...
Abrisajac

Mitochondria contain DNA, even though they don't need it any more. When they functioned as separate organisms, it was necessary, but it is unnecessary for the replication of cellular organelles.
 

 
 Mitochondria do need their DNA, and mitochondria replicate independent of the cell.
pandion

Mitochondria do need their DNA, and mitochondria replicate independent of the cell.
Both true. Mitochondrial DNA is necessary to form the various proteins present in the mitochondria.
Abrisajac

A few others that you might want to add dealing with embryology, though the term vesitigial may not be the best description.
 
 
 1) For humans,the yolk sac is vestigial.
 
 2) Human embryos also begin to form a postanal tail.
 
 3) Humans still have a diving reflex (a remnant of our evolutionary past) the helps protect against brain damage/death when drowning in cold water (the brain normally can go only about 4 minutes without oxygen before brain damage occurs, but if someone drowns in cold water, it is possible that they can go up to 30 minutes without oxygen and still not suffer brain damage).
 
 4) Dolphin embryos begin to form two hindlimbs.
 
 5) Dolphin embryos develop two "nostrils" just above the mouth, and then they fuse while migrating to the top of the head to form the blowhole.
Hi_Its_Me

Mitochondria do need their DNA, and mitochondria replicate independent of the cell.

 Fixed. Thanks for the input.
 I would like to see some from creationists now, but they don't seem to want to touch this subject...
prschuster

I found this joke at the the site that listed vestigial structures:
 
 "A mechanical engineer, a chemical engineer and a civil engineer were discussing the human body in the pub. 'The body was clearly designed by a mechanical engineer... look at all the levers and joints.' 'No no no, it was obviously designed by a chemist, it's full of amazing chemical reactions!' 'I'm sorry' said the civil engineer, 'but it was undoubtedly a civil engineer. I've run countless sewage pipes through recreational areas myself...' "
 
 
 It may also be interesting to note that there are several animals & protozoa that have incorporated algae as symbionts in their cells paralleling the endosymbiosis between archaea and cyanobacteria which led to chloroplasts (vestigial structures in all plants). Hydra & paramecium are two such examples. The Plantaris muscle is a great example of a vestigial structure, BTW. Another, more well known, example is the Auricular muscle behind the ears; it's the "ear wiggling muscle". How about the toes of humans? They are vestigial digits, which are no longer of any use for grasping objects or branches, and they have taken on a 2ndary function - that of maintaining balance for an obligately bipedal primate. And yet a more obscure example of vestigial structures involves the diminution of the haploid phase in plants & animals, becoming the pollen grain & female gametophyte in plants and the sperm & ovum in animals. Our pineal gland is like a vestigial "3rd eye", gathering light from the optic nerve instead of from a hole in the head. And don't forget that the base of the right Subclavian artery is a vestage of the right dorsal Aorta, or that the vas deferens is a vestage of the mesonephric duct, or that our teeth are modified vestages of Placoderm fish scales (which actually had dentin & enamel layers). We are truely slapped together in the most ad hoc manner imaginable... a menagerie of vestigial structures modified by hundreds of millions of years of evolution.

 Hey now, I used to unthinkingly flex my ears back/up to pull my (poorly fitting) glasses slightly but significantly closer to my face while looking down (which would make the lenses fall away from my eyes). Obviously, humans were designed to have bad eyesight so that we'd need glasses so that we could use those muscles...

 Walking-fish:
 When God created evolutionists, He made them all look like nerds with glasses and functional auricular muscles so you could pick them out in a crowd. Ear wiggling is the sign of Satan!!
Prodi

Suppose you were trying to prove that you could shoot an arrow from a bow into the center of a target. In order to prove this, you show the observer a target with an arrow in the middle of it, a bow, and you flip the lights on and off. Even if you can demonstrate all of this, you will not have proven your point. Rather, you have merely demonstrated that some of the evidence is consistent with your theory. Why? Because the evidence is consistent with other theories, most notably that you walked into the room, turned on the lights, and jammed the arrow into the center of the target. 
 
 Likewise, vestigial organs are consistent with other theories. Perhaps they were designed and later corrupted, or we haven't done enough research yet to uncover their purpose. In my experience, many supposedly vestigial structures have turned out to have a function when a little internet research is done - even though those functions are usually not necessary for life. In any case, vestigial structures, as promoted by the author of this thread, are not "proof for evolution." Rather, they are evidence against the beliefs that the author thinks - incorrectly - that all of those opposed to evolution hold.
electrolyte

Likewise, vestigial organs are consistent with other theories. Perhaps they were designed and later corrupted, or we haven't done enough research yet to uncover their purpose. In my experience, many supposedly vestigial structures have turned out to have a function when a little internet research is done - even though those functions are usually not necessary for life. In any case, vestigial structures, as promoted by the author of this thread, are not "proof for evolution." Rather, they are evidence against the beliefs that the author thinks - incorrectly - that all of those opposed to evolution hold.

 You didn't read the page I linked, did you? "Vestigial" does not mean useless. It refers to a historical leftover. As Oolon points out, birds' wings are vestigial forelimbs. They no longer support the organism's weight, but they certainly are useful. Evolution explains this.
 The plantaris muscle, on the other hand, is useless and sometimes even absent. The joints between the vertebrae of the tailbone that form during development are useless because they are later fused. Evolution explains this. No other theory that I know about does.
 If these vestigial structures are just corrupted designs, how did the corruption occur? What reason do you have for concluding that they were designed in the first place? Do you have a reasonable explanation for the existence of whale leg bones besides evolution?
Prodi

You didn't read the page I linked, did you? "Vestigial" does not mean useless. It refers to a historical leftover. As Oolon points out, birds' wings are vestigial forelimbs. They no longer support the organism's weight, but they certainly are useful. Evolution explains this.

 
 My apologies. I had assumed from the first post that all of the evolutionists in this thread were taking the "useless organ" approach to the argument.
 
 Regardless, the same argument applies to the vestigial homology variation that you propose. The evidence you bring up is evidence against your perception of creationism, not evidence in favor of evolution. The underlying assumption behind your post is that an Intelligent Designer would never use the same design twice, or would never modify a design for re-use. I don't accept that assumption. I, for one, would have a hard time accepting Intelligent Design if no two designs were alike, because that would go against everything we know about clever designs. Smart designers don't create hundreds of entirely independent concepts. Rather, they use and vary the same design many times. One has only to look at every design from nails to computers to ballistic missiles to see that much. The reason for this principle of engineering is simple - if you only make one kind of a design, you waste a lot of potentially useful similar designs. Likewise, to use your example, instead of wasting potential, the designer probably applied the same design used in a mammal's leg to make an efficient, workable wing.
 
 
The plantaris muscle, on the other hand, is useless and sometimes even absent. The joints between the vertebrae of the tailbone that form during development are useless because they are later fused. Evolution explains this. No other theory that I know about does. If these vestigial structures are just corrupted designs, how did the corruption occur? ... Do you have a reasonable explanation for the existence of whale leg bones besides evolution.

 
 I'll say from the start that I don't have explanations for all of your questions; I only have a theory with which you can work. While the number of supposedly useless structures has dropped over the years since Darwin, there are still a few whose functions remain unknown (if they even have a function). Likewise, I have no way of scientifically demonstrating a specific theory of how the organs came to be corrupted. Doing so is neither scientifically possible at this time nor necessary to defending the fundamental idea of Intelligent Design.
 
 
What reason do you have for concluding that they were designed in the first place?

 
 I don't claim to have a positive reason that they are designed. Rather, I am refuting your reason that they are not designed. If you would like to have a discussion about specified and irreducible complexity as design indicators in another thread with that topic, I would be happy to join you. As it is, however, I am only demonstrating that it is possible that these vestigial organs could have been designed.
electrolyte

The evidence you bring up is evidence against your perception of creationism, not evidence in favor of evolution.

 Nonsense. The existence of vestigial structures is evidence that life forms have undergone changes over long periods of time. In fact, the existence of vestigial structures is evidence that life forms have undergone extensive changes over long periods of time. We don't see the plantaris muscle in, say, horses, but we do in tree-dwelling monkeys; evolutionary theory tells us that we're much more closely related to monkeys than to horses, and the fact that the human plantaris muscle is existent but useless supports this conclusion. Apply this to whale pelvises for a longer-term demonstration.
 
 
The underlying assumption behind your post is that an Intelligent Designer would never use the same design twice, or would never modify a design for re-use.

 No, the underlying assumption is that an intelligent designer wouldn't include a plantaris muscle in humans. Your assumption here is that you're allowed to appeal to evolutionary change and still insist that design is involved in situations that either you arbitrarily choose or where we lack extensive knowledge. This is either special pleading or God of the Gaps, depending on which approach you've chosen for any particular argument. Both are fallacies.
 
 
I'll say from the start that I don't have explanations for all of your questions; I only have a theory with which you can work.

 But anything goes with your "theory." That makes it useless.
 
 
Doing so is neither scientifically possible at this time nor necessary to defending the fundamental idea of Intelligent Design.

 What you are probably overlooking is that "defending the fundamental idea of Intelligent Design" is and always will be scientifically impossible, precisely for the reason I stated above.
 
 
I don't claim to have a positive reason that they are designed [...] As it is, however, I am only demonstrating that it is possible that these vestigial organs could have been designed.

 Good to see you admit -- again -- that you have no support for your "theory." You can claim that "it's possible" until you're blue in the face. I can claim that "it's possible" that aliens created me yesterday and gave me knowledge of this topic so that I could have this conversation with you (and altered countless other aspects of the world such that it appeared to everybody that I'd been here since my alleged birth).
 
 
If you would like to have a discussion about specified and irreducible complexity as design indicators in another thread with that topic, I would be happy to join you.

 If you'd to start a thread on CSI and IC, you may, but I may not have time to sink into extensive roasts of the same old #### all over again. You might have to settle for short versions.
 (If you want a really active discussion about CSI and IC, try the E/C forum over at IIDB. They'll edumacate you something fierce.)
johnhanks

I don't claim to have a positive reason that they are designed. Rather, I am refuting your reason that they are not designed.

 This is a strictly pedantic interjection. You are not refuting his reason for saying they are not designed, you are disputing it. You would be refuting it only if you were demonstrating by logical argument that his position must be false.
 
 Sorry, but as a lover of argument and debate I feel strongly about the modern tendency to distort and devalue the verb 'refute'.
Prodi

Nonsense. The existence of vestigial structures is evidence that life forms have undergone changes over long periods of time. In fact, the existence of vestigial structures is evidence that life forms have undergone extensive changes over long periods of time. We don't see the plantaris muscle in, say, horses, but we do in tree-dwelling monkeys; evolutionary theory tells us that we're much more closely related to monkeys than to horses, and the fact that the human plantaris muscle is existent but useless supports this conclusion. Apply this to whale pelvises for a longer-term demonstration.

 
 Perhaps you should clarify the difference, in your opinion, between "support" and "fit within." I agree that evolution has an explanation for the examples that you have presented. However, as I mentioned in my last post, Intelligent Design also has an explanation, namely that the primate design is more similar to the human body plan than the horse design. Good engineering dictates that some designs be more similar than others to a given third design. For this reason, I doubt that this evidence supports either theory, since the evidence presented fits within both theories.
 
 
No, the underlying assumption is that an intelligent designer wouldn't include a plantaris muscle in humans.

 
 Assuming the muscle in question is functional or was corrupted at some point, why would the designer leave it out?
 
 
Your assumption here is that you're allowed to appeal to evolutionary change and still insist that design is involved in situations that either you arbitrarily choose or where we lack extensive knowledge.

 
 At what point did I appeal to evolutionary change, and how did I make that appeal?
 
 
This is either special pleading or God of the Gaps, depending on which approach you've chosen for any particular argument. Both are fallacies.

 
 God of the Gaps is a way of supporting a theory with lack of evidence. Since I am not supporting any theory at all in this discussion, it is literally impossible for me to be using the God of the Gaps fallacy. Once again, I am only defending Intelligent Design from the argument presented, not supporting it.
 
 
But anything goes with your "theory." That makes it useless.

 
 I think it's worth pointing out that you mentioned earlier in your post that the existence of the plantaris muscle demonstrates the falsehood of Intelligent Design. Setting aside the fact that your earlier statement and "anything goes with your theory" are contradictory, this provides a practical example of how Intelligent Design could be proven wrong. If our experience with intelligent designers showed us that the best way to do things is to make dozens of unrelated, under-developed concepts, ID wouldn't be an option given the current evidence. In addition, the existence of only entirely independent concepts without similarities would disprove ID. If we found perfect, gradual transformation in the fossil record and could prove in the laboratory that random variation could produce specified, complex biological structures ID would also be proven false.
 
 
If you'd to start a thread on CSI and IC, you may, but I may not have time to sink into extensive roasts of the same old #### all over again. You might have to settle for short versions.

 
 Very well. I'll start the thread immediately after I finish this post.
Prodi

Note: After making my previous post, I attempted to start the new thread, but it seems that new users are not allowed to make threads until they reach five posts. Apparently this is a guard against spam bots and the like. I will, however, start it as soon as I reach that number.
 
 Edit: And, after I reached 5 posts, I found out that users may not post links until 10 posts...so it looks like we may have a slight delay.
trebor

Perhaps you should clarify the difference, in your opinion, between "support" and "fit within." I agree that evolution has an explanation for the examples that you have presented. However, as I mentioned in my last post, Intelligent Design also has an explanation, namely that the primate design is more similar to the human body plan than the horse design. Good engineering dictates that some designs be more similar than others to a given third design. For this reason, I doubt that this evidence supports either theory, since the evidence presented fits within both theories.
 

 
 There difference is that evolution has empirical data, and I.D. does not. there is no evidence of any 'intelligent designer', nor is any mechanism proposed to let the 'intelligent designer' impliment the design. It is all 100% religion. THis has been proven in court in the Dover trial. Nor, does intelligent design actually explain anything. It is an appeal to the supernatural.
prschuster

There difference is that evolution has empirical data, and I.D. does not. there is no evidence of any 'intelligent designer', nor is any mechanism proposed to let the 'intelligent designer' impliment the design. It is all 100% religion. THis has been proven in court in the Dover trial. Nor, does intelligent design actually explain anything. It is an appeal to the supernatural.

 
 
 
 
 Walking-fish:
 Another very important assumption of Intelligent Design is that it entails intent or purpose. No ID advocate, to my knowledge, has ever been able to predict or discern what the intent of any, so called, "design" in nature has been. What did the "Designer" intend to do and for what purpose does the "Designer" plan out these designs? In other words, there is no attempt to explain the utility or value that such "designs" have to the alleged "Designer". Since ID is conspicuously silent on questions about the identity, mechanisms or intent of "designs" in nature, it can't really be a testable hypothesis, because there is nothing tangible to test for. There is only the cleverly hidden prior assumption that something must have been designed because it is too irreducubly complex or too specified to have occured without conscious intent; it begs the question.
